text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with spicy coconut shrimp bisque
we're doing a little asian occasion and
this was inspired by Chef John Besh one
of my favorites and you can read about
that on the blog but let's get started
with this amazingly delicious soup and
there's my Gulf prawns wild Gulf prawns
do not use farmed Southeast Asian prawns
do not do it please so I have a pound of
these I'm gonna peel this shells off but
do not throw away the shells because the
first step here is we're actually gonna
make a stock so there's my shrimp peeled
there's my shells I'm gonna take a
saucepan put a chunk of butter in and
I'm gonna saute those shells on medium
heat for about two minutes just until
they turn pink then I'm gonna add two
and a half cups of water and I'm gonna
bring that to a slow simmer and we're
gonna let that simmer for about 20
minutes or until we need it whichever
comes first
alright while that's simmering we're
gonna prep our prawns which are very
simple to do I'm gonna take a knife and
split it directly in half okay so hold
it like that
I'm gonna slice it right through all the
way basically sort of like butterfly in
it and then of course you're gonna
devein it you don't want veins and by
the way that's not vein okay so take
that out you can also do it from the top
down like that if that's easier for you
to hold all right so once those are all
cut and cleaned I'm gonna set those
aside in the refrigerator until needed
now we start the bisque we're gonna add
to some melted butter the Holy Trinity
green onions peppers in the form of
jalapeno pepper and some celery and why
is it called the Holy Trinity because
it's so delicious it tastes like God all
right so we're gonna sweat that on
medium heat until translucent about five
minutes or so I didn't count then we're
gonna turn the heat down to medium-low
add some flour to form a rule that's
gonna slightly thicken our bisque we're
gonna cook that for three minutes then
I'm gonna add 2 cups of prepared organic
very high-quality tomato soup you know I
love my cartons of tomato soup a very
versatile product and don't turn up your
nose if you use jarred or can tomatoes
to make sauce what's the problem with
using a very high quality soup
there isn't one so a couple cups of
tomato soup I'm gonna whisk that into my
roux
because the soup is cold and the Rouge
hot no lumps you know that right I'm
gonna strain in my shrimp stock stir
that in and like anything with a roux it
thickens as it comes to a simmer so turn
the heat up to like medium-high it will
start to simmer and bubble all right and
that's looking pretty good already so
now we're gonna add some flavorings I'm
gonna go with like 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon
of red curry paste incredibly nuclear
hot stuff so that's of course to taste
and then I'm also gonna add half a cup
of coconut milk it's gonna give it a
beautiful sweetness that just works so
perfectly with the shrimp we're gonna
taste and adjust the seasoning you could
use salt I'm gonna use a little splash
of fish sauce which is pretty salty and
we're simply gonna simmer that for about
I don't know 15 minutes or so you could
reduce it to make it thicker if you want
but for me that's perfect
at that point I'm gonna add my shrimp
turn it to low and when the shrimp are
cooked through which is only going to
take you three or four minutes you're
done and ready to eat because we
butterfly them they're in perfect little
bite sized pieces alright my shrimp are
ready how incredibly simple is that soup
alright to serve I'm gonna take some
basil leaves and do what's called a
chiffonade simply means pile up three or
four leaves roll it up like a cigar or
something else and then take a sharp
knife and slice it across into fine
ribbons and you're gonna see what we do
that in a minute I'm gonna spoon up that
soup into a hot bowl nothing says I
don't really love you like serving soup
in a cold bowl now to finish I don't
want my basil to go right into the soup
because it won't be as pretty so I'm
gonna float a little rice cracker on top
with a big pinch of my basil chiffonade
and that was an incredible soup the
sweetness from the coconut really brings
out the sweetness in the shrimp the
acidity from the tomato the
herbaceousness from the bay
a little crispy Nostromo cracker it
doesn't get any better than that so
little New Orleans meets Southeast Asian
kind of twist on a bisque like I said I
stole this from Chef John Besh he won't
care he's a nice guy so anyway I really
hope you give that a try of course this
would be amazing with lobster or crab or
any seafood so give it a try make your
own variation make it spicy as you want
make it thicker thinner or whatever just
a very very fun soup to make all the
ingredients are on food which is calm of
course and as always enjoy
